That's great Ken!

I play Go (15 kyu on KGS), and I have long been interested in 
computer Go.  I think you have a major advance here.

I have a couple of suggestions.  In line with the excellent idea of 
letting the "eye" rotate itself, you can add one more decision, and 
let the eye perform an out-of-plane 180 degree "flip".  This would be 
for right/left symetry which is also possesed by the playing field.  
To express it another way, the game initially has 8-fold symetry.  
Rotation in the plane captures only 4-fold symetry.  When you look at 
a go board you can imagine viewing it from any of the four sides, but 
you can also flip it upside down in your mind.  Your roving eye could 
do the same thing.

Another suggestion is to add a slight degree of randomness to GnuGo.
Many Faces, another well-known Go program has it.  All it takes is, 
when there are multiple moves with almost the same value, you pick 
one at random, perhaps with higher probability for the best one, if 
there is a unique best one.   

BTW, GnuGo 3.5.4 is available now, and is considerably stronger than 
3.2.

Once your program gets about as good as GnuGo, you will have to have 
it play against people, or do a tournament, or both.  Of course, you 
don't have to wait until then.
